title: Bible donated to charity shop sells for whopping $115,000
text:
A﻿ rare Bible that was donated to a charity shop in the UK has sold for a staggering £56,000 ($115,000) at auction.

The book, penned between 1815 and 1822,﻿ was the first written in Chinese, and was left at an Oxfam shop in the town of Chelmsford, about 70km north-east of central London.

Volunteers thought it was valuable and the charity put it up for auction, believing it could fetch about £800.

Part of the Bible, the first written in Chinese, that dates to 1815. (Bonhams) (Supplied)

But shop manager Nick Reeves said charity workers were "absolutely speechless" when the text went for £56,280.

"We were sat watching the bidding and just seeing it go up and up. When it finally ended, I was in complete shock. We were absolutely speechless.

"It's amazing to think that a donation from our shop could help raise that much money Oxfam. It's just wonderful."

The Bible, translated by John Lassar and Joshua Marshman, was among 23 other books donated to various Oxfam shops which were at auction last week. Their sale raised more than £105,000, which will go towards tackling poverty and inequality around the world.

Rare $2.5 million collection of Australian coins going up for auction View Gallery

They included a first edition of Charles Dickens' famous novella A Christmas Carol for £16,640﻿, while the initial English translation of Karl Marx' Manifesto of the Community Party went for £7040.

Bonham's books and manuscripts specialist Lorenza Gay said experts were stunned by the sale of the Bible.

"The Lassar and Marshman Chinese translation of the Bible was an exceedingly rare item, which we could not trace at auction previously.

title: Deadly disease overtakes COVID-19 as leading global infectious killer
text:
Tuberculosis (TB) has overtaken COVID-19 as the world's most deadly infectious disease, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO).

About 10.8 million people fell ill with the disease﻿ in 2023, while 1.25 million died.

The disease is spread through the ﻿air when a person with the disease coughs, sneezes or speaks.

READ MORE: Man hit with pole outside shop in Melbourne

Deadly disease overtakes COVID-19 as leading global infectious killer (Nine)

TB is currently treated with antibiotics that were developed in the 1950s and 1960s.

However, researchers have noted that some of the bacteria causing the disease have mutated, leading to antimicrobial resistance.

The WHO has listed antimicrobial resistance as one of the top global public health and development threats.

TB primarily affects the lungs, with the bacteria being spread when an infected person coughs, sneezes or even sings.

"This can put tiny droplets with the bacteria into the air. Another person can then breathe in the droplets, and the bacteria enter the lungs where they can cause disease," the WHO said.

READ MORE: Nine hurt in electric shock incident at Gold Coast school

TB is the world's deadliest infectious disease caused by a single pathogen. (Nine)

Photographers reflect on tragedies and triumphs of the pandemic View Gallery

The University of Queensland's Professor Antje Blumenthal said a quarter of the population carries the bacteria responsible for causing TB.

But not everyone who is infected with TB bacteria will develop TB disease," Blumenthal said.

"The bacteria have been with us for thousands of years and they are really well adapted to survive and thrive in our bodies," she said.

"TB treatment currently requires several months of a cocktail of antibiotics and can take more than a year to complete.

"What is needed is new knowledge and strategies that will help us develop treatments that act faster and have less side effects. This can be new antibiotics but also might be strategies to help the body's immune response better control the bacteria. "

Blumenthal hoped that, one day, these new treatments could be combined with antibiotics to make TB treatment faster and more effective.

title: Here's how a blanket work from home ban could ruin your daily commute
text:
The work from home debate has transformed into a hot federal election issue in Australia after the Coalition flagged plans to mirror Trump's tough stance on forcing public workers back into the office.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese yesterday championed the right to work from home and offer worker flexibility after Opposition Leader Peter Dutton suggested all public servants should be in the office full time.

Albanese also backed Labor-led research which found the average worker will be $5000 more out of pocket if they are made to commute to an office five days a week.

READ MORE: CCTV released after man shot in Melbourne

Hundreds of thousands of workers returning to the office could change your daily commute. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

If public sector employees – of which there are 365,400 working in federal government – can no longer work from home, who does this impact?

According to analysis of Australian Bureau of Statistics data from the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), one in three workers will be negatively affected by a blanket return to office order.﻿

More than 600,000 Australians work from home nationally in order to save money or avoid a commute, the ABS data shows.

If a large chunk of this widespread demographic gets back on the roads every morning and afternoon, traffic congestion will impact everyone, the ACTU said.

Meanwhile, 320,000 of these workers say they need remote work for care responsibilities.﻿

Another one million Australian workers also report working from home in order to "catch up" on work after hours.

The ACTU said these workers will be forced to stay later at the office and will lose their "right to disconnect".

The ACTU said traffic congestion will be far worse under a policy like this. (Getty)

"Working people in our outer suburbs face some of the longest and most expensive commutes," said ACTU president Michele O'Neil.

"Forcing hundreds of thousands of workers back on the roads will mean less time with kids and more time in traffic."

O'Neil said an order like Dutton's proposal would "kill productivity" and disadvantage women.

"This would be an instant productivity killer, because flexible work has pushed women's workforce participation to record highs, as one million women joined the workforce in the last four years," O'Neil added.

READ MORE: Man hit with pole outside shop in Melbourne

PM Anthony Albanese championed WFH yesterday after speaking about the Coalition's plans. (9News)

Albanese yesterday said the $5000 figure was an average estimate which could be much higher for those living in capital cities such as Sydney or Melbourne.

"It makes an enormous difference... in terms of their hip pocket," he said.

Following a mixed reaction from Dutton's pre-election work from home policy, the opposition leader later softened his approach and said he wanted to see remote work return ﻿to "pre-COVID levels" when around 20 per cent of the workforce worked from home.

title: Billions in cost-of-living relief coming in tomorrow's budget
text:
Australians can expect another significant boost to cost-of-living relief in tomorrow's federal budget as the government gears up for an election in May .

While it had been presumed for months that an expected early election would get in the way of the budget, Tropical Cyclone Alfred delayed the calling of the vote , meaning Treasurer Jim Chalmers will have to hand down the national accounts as scheduled on March 25.

Because of that, there have been far fewer early announcements than in previous years, but the government has now revealed at least a few of the new measures it will be handing down this week.

Here's what﻿ you can expect tomorrow.

Treasurer Jim Chalmers is preparing to hand down the federal budget on March 25. (Polly Hanning/Nine)

Major bulk-billing boost and cheaper PBS medicines

Health ﻿has been a significant focus for the government in the lead-up to the next election, highlighted by two major policy announcements.

The first, unveiled in February, is an $8.5 billion boost for Medicare to expand bulk billing in a policy it says will deliver 18 million extra bulk-billed GP visits each year, saving Australians a combined $859 million a year by 2030.

The second, announced just days from the budget, is a $689 million pledge to reduce the maximum cost of a majority of medicines listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS), down from $31.60 to $25﻿.

That second announcement, which comes as US pharmaceutical giants lobby President Donald Trump to target the PBS in a new round of tariffs, will deliver Australians combined savings of $200 million a year, according to the government, and will start on January 1, 2026.

Both policies have been backed by the opposition, so will come into effect regardless of who wins the next election.

Many medicines listed on the PBS will get cheaper from January 1, 2026. (Nine)

Energy bill relief

The centrepiece of last year's budget was the $3.5 billion in energy bill relief – an automatic $300 rebate, spread over the course of the financial year, for every household in the country, and that is, as expected, being extended this year.

The policy will now run through until the end of the year, providing all Australian households with a further﻿ $150 off their power bills , at a cost of $1.8 billion.

It comes after the national energy regulator approved price increases of up to 9 per cent from July 1.

According to Treasury estimates, the move will reduce headline inflation by around half a percentage point, and reduce household bills by 7.5 per cent on average nationally.

While the opposition slammed the move as a "desperate act" and a "Ponzi scheme", it also promised to support the move so, once again, it will be implemented regardless of the election result.

The government says the extension of energy relief will reduce household bills by 7.5 per cent. (Luis Enrique Ascui/The Age)

Boost for Australian-made goods as tariffs hit

One of the big economic uncertainties plaguing financial markets at the moment is US President Donald Trump's explosion of tariffs.

Australia has been hit by Trump's 25 per cent ﻿tax on all steel and aluminium imported into the United States, and while we shouldn't expect a retaliatory tariff in the budget – that was ruled out by Albanese – there's set to be some kind of response.

Local manufacturers fear a flood of cheap, international produce onto the Australian market from all the other nations that have also been denied free access to American consumers, which would be a significant business challenge.

Albanese has flagged support for local industry will be handed down.

"In the March budget, we'll provide additional support for our 'Buy Australian' campaign which we'll be announcing as part of the budget process," the prime minister said in his press conference responding to the introduction of Trump's tariffs.

A couple of days later, he gave another hint on the topics.

"We have great products and as part of the budget in a couple of weeks' time, you'll see a spiced-up Made in Australia Plan﻿," he said.

Expect to see incentives for Australians to buy locally made products after Donald Trump's steel and aluminium tariffs. (AAP)

A budget deficit

﻿After two straight years of surpluses, the budget will return to the red in 2025.

﻿This has been flagged for quite some time; last year's surplus was always forecast to be followed by a return to deficit. (To put things into context, 2023 and 2024 are the only two surpluses Australia has recorded since 2008.)

While we don't know what the exact figure will be, in December's Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook (MYEFO), Treasury was forecasting a deficit of $26.9 billion in this year's budget.

A week before budget day, Chalmers said that figure will be pretty close to the mark.

"Revenue upgrades have actually come off very significantly since the highs of October 2022," he said.

"Treasury doesn't expect the bottom line this year or over the forward estimates to change very substantially from MYEFO."﻿

Chalmers has flagged the deficit is likely to be in the mid-$20 billions. (Alex Ellinghausen/SMH)

Massive student debt discount

The roughly 3 million Australians who have student debt will get a welcome boost on June 1 when ﻿their outstanding balances are cut by 20 per cent .

The one-off discount represents a massive $16 billion in student debt reduction – more than five times larger than last year's move to retrospectively lower the indexation applied to those debts.

The new measure was announced by the government as an election promise in November, and will now need to be included in this year's budget.

All Australians with student debt will get a big saving following the budget. (Louie Douvis/AFR)

Subsidised childcare for everyone﻿

Like﻿ the student debt discount, this was an election promise unveiled in late 2024, well after the last budget: three days a week of subsidised childcare to families with a combined income of less than $530,000 a year.

The activity test will also be scrapped to make it easier for low-income parents to access cheaper childcare, a measure recommended by the Productivity Commission and long called for by economists.

The policy will come into effect on January 1, 2026, if Labor wins the federal election, and will cost $427 million over five years.

Albanese and Education Minister Jason Clare (right) unveiled the childcare changes last year. (Paul Jeffers/The Age)

Other announcements ﻿

There are a number of other policies that will form a part of the 2025 federal budget, including:

A new $1 billion fund to build and expand early education centres﻿

$1 billion ﻿to reserve land for a future rail line linking Western Sydney Airport with south-west Sydney suburbs

$30 million for the restoration of the Adass Israel Synagogue, which was firebombed last year, as well as a further $1.2 million for security upgrades.﻿

$2.9 million to help grocery suppliers "stand up" to Woolworths and Coles.

A $44.5 million boost for Australia's intelligence capabilities to implement the recommendations of an independent review.

$800 million to expand the eligibility criteria for the Help to Buy shared equity housing scheme .

﻿$54 million to boost the prefabricated home construction industry.

title: Pope Francis back home after life-threatening double pneumonia
text:
A weak and frail Pope Francis has returned home to the Vatican from the hospital after surviving a five-week, life-threatening bout of pneumonia, making a surprise stop at his favourite basilica on the way home before beginning two months of prescribed rest and recovery.

The motorcade carrying the 88-year-old pope entered the Perugino gate into Vatican City on Sunday morning (Sunday night AEDT), and Francis was seen in the front passenger seat wearing nasal tubes to give him supplemental oxygen.

During the trip home from Gemelli hospital, Francis took a slight detour to bring him to the St Mary Major basilica, where his favourite icon of the Madonna is located and where he always goes to pray after a foreign visit. Francis didn't get out of the car, but handed a bouquet of flowers to the cardinal to place in front of the Salus populi Romani icon, a Byzantine-style painting on wood that is revered by Romans.

Pope Francis gestures as he appears at a window of the Agostino Gemelli Polyclinic in Rome, Sunday, March 23, 2025, where he has been treated for bronchitis and bilateral pneumonia since February 14. (AP Photo/Domenico Stinellis)

﻿Before leaving the hospital, Francis gave a thumbs up and acknowledged the crowd after he was wheeled out onto the balcony overlooking the main entry. Hundreds of people had gathered on a brilliant Sunday morning to say goodbye.

"I see this woman with the yellow flowers. Brava!" a tired and bloated-looking Francis said. He gave a weak sign of the cross before being wheeled back inside.

Chants of "Viva il papa!" and "Papa Francesco" erupted from the crowd, which included patients who had been wheeled outside just to catch his brief appearance.

Doctors, who announced his planned release at a Saturday evening (early Sunday AEDT) news conference, said he needs two months of rest and convalescence, during which he should refrain from meeting with big groups of people or exerting himself. But they said eventually he should be able to resume all his normal activities.

His return home, after the longest hospitalisation of his 12-year papacy and the second-longest in recent papal history, brought tangible relief to the Vatican and Catholic faithful who have been anxiously following 38 days of medical ups and downs and wondering if Francis would make it.

"Today I feel a great joy," said Dr Rossella Russomando, a doctor from Salerno who didn't treat Francis but was at Gemelli on Sunday.

"It is the demonstration that all our prayers, all the rosary prayers from all over the world, brought this grace."

Pope Francis gestures as he appears at a window of the Agostino Gemelli Polyclinic in Rome, on Sunday, March 23, 2025. (AP Photo/Domenico Stinellis)

Pope is happy to go home

At the Vatican on Sunday, pilgrims flocked as they have all year to St Peter's Basilica to participate in the 2025 Holy Year. They swarmed St Peter's Square and progressed through the Holy Door in groups, while big TV screens in the square were turned on to broadcast Francis' hospital greeting live.

No special arrangements have been made at the Domus Santa Marta, the Vatican hotel next to the basilica where Francis lives in a two-room suite on the second floor. Francis will have access to supplemental oxygen and 24-hour medical care as needed, though his personal physician, Dr Luigi Carbone, said he hoped Francis would progressively need less and less assistance breathing as his lungs recover.

While the pneumonia infection has been successfully treated, Francis will continue to take oral medication for quite some time to treat the fungal infection in his lungs and continue his respiratory and physical physiotherapy.

"For three or four days he's been asking when he can go home, so he's very happy," Carbone said.

Faithful and nuns wait a Pope Francis appearing at a window of the Agostino Gemelli Polyclinic in Rome, Sunday, March 23, 2025 (AP Photo/Riccardo De Luca)

Two life-threatening crises

The Argentine pope, who has chronic lung disease and had part of one lung removed as a young man, was admitted to Gemelli on February 14 after a bout of bronchitis worsened.

Doctors first diagnosed a complex bacterial, viral and fungal respiratory tract infection and soon thereafter, pneumonia in both lungs. Blood tests showed signs of anemia, low blood platelets and the onset of kidney failure, all of which later resolved after two blood transfusions.

The most serious setbacks began on February 28, when Francis experienced an acute coughing fit and inhaled vomit, requiring the use of a noninvasive mechanical ventilation mask to help him breathe. He suffered two more respiratory crises a few days later, which required doctors to manually aspirate "copious" amounts of mucus from his lungs, at which point he began sleeping with the ventilation mask at night to help his lungs clear the accumulation of fluids.

Pope Francis waves as he appears at a window of the Agostino Gemelli Polyclinic in Rome, on Sunday, March 23, 2025. (AP Photo/Andrew Medichini)

He was never intubated and at no point lost consciousness. Doctors reported he always remained alert and cooperative, though they say he has probably lost a bit of weight given a natural loss of appetite.

"Unfortunately yes, there was a moment when many were saying that he might not make it. And it was painful for us," said Mario Balsamo, the owner of coffee shop in front of Gemelli.

"Instead, today with the discharge, we are very happy that he is well and we hope he will recover soon and will recover his strength."

Pope Francis leaves in a car the Agostino Gemelli Polyclinic in Rome, on Sunday, March 23, 2025. (AP Photo/Marco Ravagli)

'I'm still alive!'

Dr Sergio Alfieri, the medical and surgical chief at Gemelli who coordinated Francis' medical team, stressed that not all patients who develop such a severe case of double pneumonia survive, much less are released from the hospital. He said Francis' life was at risk twice, during the two acute respiratory crises, and that the pope at the time understandably lost his typical good sense of humour.

"But one morning we went to listen to his lungs and we asked him how he was doing. When he replied, 'I'm still alive,' we knew he was OK and had gotten his good humor back," he said.

Alfieri confirmed that Francis was still having trouble speaking due to the damage to his lungs and respiratory muscles. But he said such problems were normal, especially in older patients, and predicted his voice would eventually return to normal.

Pope Francis waves as he appears at a window of the Agostino Gemelli Polyclinic in Rome, on Sunday, March 23, 2025. (Francesco Sforza/Vatican press office via AP)

No confirmed appointments for now

The Vatican spokesman, Matteo Bruni, declined to confirm any upcoming events, including a scheduled audience on April 8 with King Charles III or Francis' participation in Easter services at the end of the month. But Carbone said he hoped Francis might be well enough to travel to Turkey at the end of May to participate in an important ecumenical anniversary.

Francis is also returning to the Vatican in the throes of a Holy Year, the once-every-quarter-century celebration scheduled to draw more than 30 million pilgrims to Rome this year. The pope has already missed several Jubilee audiences and will presumably miss several more, but Vatican officials say his absence hasn't significantly impacted the numbers of expected pilgrims arriving.

Only St John Paul II recorded a longer hospitalisation in 1981, when he spent 55 days at Gemelli for minor surgery and treatment of an infection.

title: Fire breaks out in Disney's EPCOT theme park in Florida
text:
A large fire has broken out at the EPCOT theme park at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Florida .

The blaze sent crowds of people fleeing as thick plumes of smoke were seen in the air near the park's French Pavilion.

Disney World told local media the fire started on Saturday afternoon (local time) after a walk-in cooler caught fire.

A ride was evacuated following the fire, which began in a walk-in cooer. (Facebook)

Guests had to be evacuated from the Remy's Ratatouille Adventure ride.

No injuries have been reported.

Disney confirmed the fire had been extinguished by around 7.20pm local time.

Social media footage of the blaze shows dark smoke billowing into the sky.

No injuries have been reported and the park closed as normal. (Facebook)

Epcot is a theme park located at the Walt Disney World Resort in Orlando, one of four parks at the resort.

It has now shut as normal following the fire, which broke out around two hours before closing time.

title: Norris 'nervous and excited' as teammate Piastri claims F1 win
text:
Formula 1 championship leader Lando Norris says he is "nervous and excited" about the prospect of a season-long battle with Australian teammate Oscar Piastri.

McLaren, the 2024 constructors' champion, has made the perfect start to the year with Norris and Piastri claiming the first two grands prix of 2025.

Following Piastri's flawless performance in China to win the grand prix, a day after finishing second in the sprint race, the Australian showed he was a genuine contender for this year's drivers' championship.

Piastri wins Chinese grand prix Photo shows F1 driver Oscar Piastri smiles as he hugs McLaren boss Zak Brown on the track at the Chinese Grand Prix. Australian Formula 1 driver Oscar Piastri has won the Chinese Grand Prix in Shanghai after starting on pole for the first time.

Norris finished second in the drivers' championship last season, making a late charge at Max Verstappen, and was considered a strong candidate to be crowned champion at the end of the season.

But with McLaren telling both drivers they are free to race each other and go for glory, Norris said he expected to be battling his partner throughout the year as they both chase a maiden world title.

"I'm sure we’re going to have some closer racing at some point. I think we’re both excited — probably nervous and excited at the same time — as I’m sure the team will be," Norris said in the drivers' press conference after finishing second in Sunday's grand prix.

"But we’re ready. We know that as much as we work together and we have a good time and enjoy ourselves, we both know we want to try and beat each other and show who’s best. And that’s inevitable.

"So there’s no point trying to hide away from that fact or make something of it. We’re two competitors who both want to win."

Piastri's victory in Shanghai was the third grand prix victory of his career, following triumphs in Hungary and Azerbaijan last season.

The Chinese GP win adds to victories in Hungary and Azerbaijan last year. (AP)

But the Australian has described Sunday's victory as "the most satisfying", because there was not any fault during the entire weekend from the Melbourne-born racer.

"The two wins I had previously were very different, and I think this one's been the most complete," he said.

"I think we started with a car that was quick, but pretty tricky at times, and I think we did a good job of trying to tackle that.

"And to come away with this result is a perfect end to the weekend."

The win has softened the heartache from round one in Australia when Piastri blew his chance at a podium, or even a race win, when he spun off track while running second.

The Australian was consistently quick that weekend as well, giving him belief more great results are on the horizon — starting with the Japanese Grand Prix in a fortnight.

"I think there's still going to be bumps along the road and things we can try and work on, but ultimately I think we're in a pretty happy place at the moment and, yeah, excited for the rest of the year," he said.

Round three of the Formula 1 championship will be held in Suzuka at the Japanese Grand Prix on Sunday, April 6.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

title: 'Age is just a number' as Vonn creates skiing history
text:
Lindsey Vonn's return to the podium — six years since stepping away from ski racing, 11 months since her partial knee replacement, and four months since announcing her return — hit her hard in the finish area.

Struggling to catch her breath, but still managing the energy to raise her ski poles in celebration, the tears fell.

They were for joy and relief that she could even make it back to the World Cup circuit. They were for the satisfaction of proving all her doubters wrong.

They were, she explained, for showing "this adventure that I set myself on is worth something".

Vonn concluded her comeback season at age 40 with a second-place finish in a World Cup super-G race on Sunday at Sun Valley, Idaho, that was won by Swiss stand-out Lara Gut-Behrami.

Vonn became the oldest female Alpine ski racer to step on the podium of a World Cup race by six years.

"It was [expletive] hard," Vonn said.

"This is not easy what I'm doing. It just felt really good to say I did it. That I can still do it."

Vonn found her vintage form while flying down the twisting and steep Challenger course at the World Cup finals. The 82-time World Cup winner — along with three-time Olympic medallist — glanced at the scoreboard and soaked in the roar of the large crowd.

Lindsey Vonn will aim to compete at the 2026 Olympics. (Getty Images: Ezra Shaw)

It is a moment she will cherish.

"Age is just a number," Vonn said.

"If you feel good and you're mentally still driven and you work hard, you can achieve anything you set your mind to."

She was motivated by the doubters, too — those who criticised her for making a return.

"Sometimes the negative voices, they drive me more than the positive ones," Vonn said.

"I use all that as fuel. It propelled me through some tough times this year. I knew that I could do it.

"When I crossed the finish line, there's a lot of relief to be where I know I can be and to silence so many negative voices that have just been surrounding me, it feels like, all season. It was just a nice exclamation point to put on the season."

This was Vonn's first World Cup podium spot since March 15, 2018, when she finished third in a super-G in Åre, Sweden. A year later in Åre, she earned downhill bronze at the world championships before calling time on her career due to her knee.

Vonn received a titanium knee last April and was feeling so good that she announced in November her plans for a return.

"I just continue to prove that anything is possible," Vonn said. "I've been knocked down so many times in my life personally, physically, mentally, beat down and I always pick myself back up. It's not always easy.

"It's actually really [expletive] hard work. But that's what it takes, putting one foot in front of the other and getting through the hard days. When you keep putting one foot in front of the other, it leads you to a place like today."

Before the race, her father Alan Kildow took her by the arm and just said: "Fearless."

Lindsey Vonn has 138 career World Cup podiums. (Getty Images: Agence Zoom/Christophe Pallot)

She listened.

"Of all the races, of all the courses she's been on, this one really suits her," Kildow said of the redesigned Sun Valley course.

"A very clean, technically sound run could go a long run. She skied it like she had to."

It was Vonn's 138th career World Cup podium in her 408th World Cup start. She is within one of tying the most starts by a female Alpine racer, a mark held by Renate Götschl of Austria.

One skier not surprised by Vonn's success is 34-year-old Italian racer Federica Brignone.

"She's Lindsey Vonn," said Brignone, who officially clinched the downhill discipline on Saturday after the race was cancelled, along with the overall crown.

"She's not somebody coming back from another injury. She has qualities and she's an amazing champion. Today, she put all the pieces [together] and did an amazing race."

Gut-Behrami finished in a time of 1 minute, 12.35 seconds — edging Vonn by 1.29 seconds — to earn the season-long super-G crystal globe by overtaking Brignone.

Gut-Behrami trailed by five points heading into Sunday's race. Gut-Behrami found plenty of speed and took some calculated risks to glide through the course. Brignone finished third, 1.33 seconds behind Gut-Behrami.

The final season-long super-G standings ended up Gut-Behrami, Brignone and Sofia Goggia of Italy.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"Two days ago, I finally found the happiness again on skis," Gut-Behrami explained.

"It's easier to ski fast when you're enjoying what you're doing. I've been looking for that the entire season."

The next race at the World Cup finals is on Tuesday with a women's giant slalom.

For Vonn, the season is over. Her plan is to rest a few weeks and then head to Europe for more testing of her ski equipment.

"I literally gave every single last ounce of energy that I had in the last race of the season," Vonn explained.

"I could barely breathe [at the finish], maybe because I was crying.

"It was a great race."

AP

title: The surprising health benefits linked to having a baby at 35 and older
text:
Having my son at age 36, I was made aware of the risks associated with my "advanced maternal age" pregnancy.

I never heard about any specific benefits. The only thing I knew for sure was that it was the right time for me.

But there are several evidence-based advantages associated with late-age births — for both mum and bub. And given women are increasingly having babies when they are older, obstetrician Nisha Khot says we should be talking about them more.

"In the medical profession we are very good at talking about risks [but] often not equally good at talking about benefits," says Dr Khot, who is the vice president of the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RANZCOG).

"It's not all doom and gloom."

Noa Sterling, an obstetrician gynaecologist based in the US, has a passion for demystifying long-held myths about older mums, and uses her social platforms to break down the research.

She says her role is to "turn down the dial" of fear for people who are pregnant later in life.

"Advanced maternal age doesn't automatically mean high risk … that's one myth that I think is still enduring."

Our experts Dr Nisha Khot, obstetrician and vice president of RANZCOG.

Dr Noa Sterling, US obstetrician gynaecologist and content creator

Dr Chantel Thornton, specialist breast cancer surgeon at Epworth HealthCare

Dr Rui Wang, reproductive epidemiologist at the University of Sydney

Risks associated with advanced maternal age

Australian women are increasingly having children later in life.

Before 1991, only 5 per cent of first-time mothers were over the age of 35. By 2020, that figure increased to 17 per cent.

Women on motherhood after 40 Photo shows Gayle Dickerson takes a selfie with her son at a cafe table We hear from four mothers about the highs of lows of parenting after 40.

Before we get to the positives these mothers and their children may experience, it's important to acknowledge there are associated risks.

As we get older, Dr Sterling says we are more likely to have chronic medical conditions such as hypertension, diabetes, and thyroid disorders.

"Some of the risks are because people who are 35 [and older] are more likely to have other medical problems going on."

But even for healthy people, there are still some increased risks.

"That is mainly because there's an increased risk of chromosomal abnormalities, because as we age, our eggs — the DNA in our eggs — gets damaged," Dr Sterling says, adding that an embryo with a chromosomal abnormality is more likely to result in pregnancy loss.

Dr Noa Sterling uses her social platforms to educate followers on advanced maternal age. (Supplied)

Pre-term birth, pre-eclampsia, and gestational diabetes are other examples of health risks associated with later age pregnancy.

Dr Khot says the likelihood of a caesarean-section is greater.

"[That] may relate to pre-existing medical conditions like diabetes or pregnancy complications, or it may sometimes be maternal choice.

"Doctors would intervene if there was a medical or pregnancy complication and may, in some cases, recommend caesarean section as a safer birth option."

Australian research from 2017 found advanced maternal age was associated with a two-fold increased likelihood of birth by caesarean section in both nulliparous (not having given birth previously) and multiparous (having given birth previously) women.

However, the majority of these women birthed vaginally.

ABC Lifestyle Get a mid-week boost and receive easy recipes, wellbeing ideas, and home and garden tips in your inbox every Wednesday. You’ll also receive a monthly newsletter of our best recipes.

Women of advanced maternal age are at increased risk of stillbirth, but only if it's their first baby, explains Dr Sterling.

"If you are advanced maternal age, but it's not your first baby, you are actually at a lower risk of stillbirth than a younger person who's having their first baby.

"For whatever reason, stillbirth is much more common with first pregnancies than it is with subsequent [ones]."

And there is evidence that being older at the birth of a woman's first child is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer.

Chantel Thornton, a specialist breast cancer surgeon at Epworth HealthCare in Melbourne, says in the immediate period after giving birth, there is a higher index of breast cancer in all women.

"That risk is higher in women of mature age," she says, because "when you are older, you are already at increased risk of breast cancer merely by age alone, and therefore if you add the hormonal surge of pregnancy, your risk of breast cancer will be slightly elevated compared to women who have never had children."

However in advanced years, "when it is more common to get breast cancer in the 60s and 70s", Dr Thornton says the breast cancer risk is actually lower than for women who have never had children, indicating a protective factor later in life.

Maternal longevity and improved cognition

Advanced maternal age doesn't automatically mean high risk, says Dr Sterling. (Pexels)

Several studies, including 2016 research involving more than 20,000 women, have found a link between late-age births and maternal longevity, but note a direct casual relationship cannot be established.

"[Research shows] later age at last birth, or giving birth at a later age, is associated with increased longevity, meaning you're more likely to have a longer life," Dr Sterling says.

"We see that people who give birth later on in life have longer telomeres, which are the non-coding end of chromosomes that help protect our chromosomes from degradation."

Basically, longer telomeres mean cells can divide more often before deteriorating or dying.

Researchers aren't sure if people who are able to have children later in life were always going to have longer telomeres, or if pregnancy later in life makes it that way, explains Dr Sterling.

"I wouldn't be so quick to dismiss [the latter] because we know that the DNA from our children stays with us always, and we know that it can actually help our body repair itself."

On DNA, Dr Sterling says there is research showing women who have more male DNA from being pregnant with a boy may have lower rates of dementia.

And she says more generally, there is some evidence women who have been pregnant later in life may have better cognitive function.

"That may be because in pregnancy, your progesterone [and] your estrogen get like 20 to 40 times higher than it is pre-pregnancy," Dr Sterling says.

" That big hormone load may actually be protective for cognitive function. "

It all sounds positive, but Dr Khot says we should consider "we don't [always] know the extent to which other underlying factors contribute to these beneficial effects rather than pregnancy alone."

Those underlying factors may include needing to staying active and engaged for longer — just to name two possibilities.

"You could imagine if you are having a baby when you are older, a toddler is going to be active, so you will have to be active [for longer]," Dr Khot says.

"Once your child goes to school you will be helping them, using brain cells for longer."

Dr Nisha Knot is the vice-president at RANZCOG. (Supplied)

She adds health benefits may also come down to women having babies later in life being more financially stable than younger mums, and therefore more able to invest in healthcare.

Reproductive epidemiologist Rui Wang from the University of Sydney says while promising, the above research should be interpreted with caution.

He says there are a lot of factors after birth that can impact longevity and cognition, for example, but are not addressed in the above studies.

Some of the cohorts used, for example from the 1990s, may also not be applicable to the current population, Dr Wang says.

Much of the research also looks at age at the birth of someone's last child, as opposed to their age when having their first.

"All this kind of evidence, it's very promising," Dr Rui says, but adds further research needs to be done to paint a clearer picture.

Academic and health benefits for kids

Children born to older parents may do better in school, be healthier, and have fewer social, emotional and behavioural issues, says Dr Sterling.

"And we see this still when we control for socio-economic factors," Dr Sterling says of research in this area.

Researchers can control for socio-economic factors by collecting data on relevant aspects like income, education level, and occupation, and then statistically adjusting the analysis to account for potential influences of these factors on the study outcome.

Dr Sterling says that could indicate we get "better at parenting as we get older", regardless of what money or education we have access to, for example.

" It's too bad that our peak fertility is really 18 to 31. "

For example, a 2012 study published in the British Medical Journal found language development in children was associated with improvements with increasing maternal age.

The same study also found children of older parents were also less likely to present to the emergency room with unintentional injuries.

A 2016 study published in the European Journal of Developmental Psychology found older maternal age was associated with fewer behavioural, social and emotional difficulties in children at age seven and at age 11 (but not at age 15).

What are some of the positives you've experienced having children later in life? Share with us via lifestyle@abc.net.au

Fertility and pregnancy risks separate issues

Dr Sterling says the information she shares isn't about encouraging women to wait longer to have babies. But to support those who, for whatever reason, have become pregnant later in life.

"It's really important for us to continue to raise awareness and to talk about the fact that fertility declines as we age; we see quite a significant drop-off in fertility in the late 30s and certainly 40 plus.

"But once that individual is pregnant, rather than just fearmonger and scare them about all of the things that they're increased risk for, talk to them [and say] there's benefits to this pregnancy for you and for this baby."

Dr Khot says it is useful to focus less on age, and more on the individual.

"There are risks that go with a teen being pregnant, and [risks with] being 48 and pregnant, and benefit in both."

title: Queensland to get $2.8b for schools in 'biggest ever' federal funding deal
text:
Queensland will join other states and territories in a deal to make up the "funding shortfall" for public education, with an extra $2.8 billion from the Commonwealth over the next decade.

Speaking with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in Canberra on Monday, Premier David Crisafulli said the Better and Fairer Schools Agreement is the "biggest investment in schools in our nation's history".

Queensland is the last to sign up to the deal, under which the Commonwealth has agreed to lift its share of public school funding from 20 to 25 per cent.

States would also be required to increase funding of public schools to 75 per cent of the minimum amount recommended by the 2012 Gonski Review, meaning the schools would become "fully funded".

New South Wales was the second last to join, when it signed on earlier this month.

Speaking with Anthony Albanese in Canberra on Monday, David Crisafulli says the deal is the "biggest investment in schools in our nation's history". (ABC News: Matt Roberts)

Mr Crisafulli said Queensland's state schools had challenges other states and territories didn't.

"We are the most decentralised state. We've got a large portion of rural and regional and Indigenous schools," he said.

"We have challenges because of that, not just geographically, but challenges that have historically been baked in as a result, our NAPLAN results aren't what we have wanted to see in recent years.

" What this does is give us a decade-long commitment to be able to turn the funding shortfall around, and with that will come the ability to turn those results around. "

Mr Albanese said it was an "historic day".

He said the agreement would fully fund every public school student in Australia.

Full funding is the amount set out by the Schooling Resource Standard (SRS) — an estimate of how much funding a school needs to meet students' needs recommended by the Gonski review.

"Today, we reach the point for the first time in Australian history where every student, public and private, will be delivered the school funding that they deserve, the school resourcing standard that was identified by David Gonski more than a decade ago," Mr Albanese said.

The Coalition's Gonski 2.0 reforms required states to fund public schools at 75 per cent of the SRS on top of the feds' 20 per cent, leaving a 5 per cent gap.

Currently, public schools in all states and territories, except the ACT, are billions of dollars short of the funding needed to meet minimum standards.

'Not a blank cheque'

Mr Albanese said the deal was the "biggest-ever investment" in Queensland public schools by the Commonwealth.

It is expected to support 560,000 public school students in the state.

Public school funding, explained Photo shows A graphic showing a group of school children and federal education minister Jason Clare There was a major development around funding for public schools this week. Let us break it down for you.

"It isn't a blank cheque, this money is tied to real reforms like evidence-based teaching practices, phonics and numeracy checks, catch-up tutoring and more mental health support."

Overall, the agreement will bring about an extra $16.5 billion in federal funding to the country's public schools from 2025.

The parties will now sign the Queensland Bilateral Agreement to tie funding to reforms to "help students catch up, keep up and finish school".

They include year 1 phonics and numeracy checks to identify students who need extra help, targeted catch-up support, wellbeing initiatives and schemes to improve teacher retention and reduce teachers' workloads.

There will also be targets to achieve, including that by 2030 the proportion of students finishing high school will be the highest it has ever been.

Other targets include lowering the number of students in the NAPLAN needing "additional support" by 10 per cent, increasing the number of students at the "strong" and "exceeding" proficiency reading and numeracy levels by 10 per cent by 2030, and increasing student attendance rate nationally to the 2019 level of 91.4 per cent.

Will Dutton support the boost?

Australian Education Union federal president Correna Haythorpe said Monday's announcement was "the final agreement we've been waiting for".

She called on opposition leader Peter Dutton to match the federal government's funding.

"Are you going to back in-full funding, and will you commit to the full 25 per cent Commonwealth share that we know is needed for public schools across the nation?"

Queensland Teachers' Union president Cresta Richardson says the funding would help manage the challenges teachers face, like workload. (ABC News)

The Coalition has previously pledged to do so. But earlier this month, Shadow Education Minister Sarah Henderson said the government was yet to "come clean" on the details of its agreements with states and territories.

Queensland Teachers' Union president Cresta Richardson said it was a day she didn't think "would ever come".

"In Queensland, we have some issues with workload, it's crippling. Teacher shortages as well as occupational violence, but this money will go some way to support resourcing to manage some of these issues," she said.

Where's the money coming from?

Asked whether the $2.8b for Queensland will be in the upcoming budget, Mr Albanese said "most" of the spending was in the mid-year budget update delivered in December.

But he said there would be some "additional investment given to Queensland that will be accounted for in the pre-election fiscal outlook".

Mr Crisafulli said he had brought forward some state funding to "secure the deal".

"We've under-invested in public education as a state for too long, and this was an opportunity too good to miss," he said.

title: Inside a remote island community's bicycle revolution
text:
On the face of it, bicycles should be a great way to get around on Thursday Island, or "TI", in the Torres Strait.

The 3.5-square-kilometre tropical island has a designated cycleway and most things are a five to 10-minute ride away.

There is no public transport and fuel prices — $2.55 a litre for unleaded — are among the highest in the country.

But after moving her young family to TI from New South Wales in 2023, Sarah Tedder was struck by the lack of people pedalling around.

"As I was riding around with my kids, I just wasn't seeing many other bikes at all," she said.

Ms Tedder's family moved from Port Kembla to Thursday Island in 2023 with their cargo bike. (Supplied: Sarah Tedder)

It turned out bicycles just weren't a thing on TI.

There was no bike shop on the island and shipping them from Cairns, the nearest mainland city more than 1,000 kilometres away, was expensive.

After surveying community members nearly a year ago, Ms Tedder found while some kids had a bike, it was a different story for adults, with many relying on taxis to get their children to school or run errands.

"People were telling me they were spending $100 a week on taxis," Ms Tedder said.

Along with a group of locals and the mayor, she has since led a bicycle revolution — Mobilise TI — to improve access to bikes for the island's nearly 3,000 residents.

Mobilise TI runs a monthly bike hospital and bike exchange. (Supplied: Sarah Tedder)

Since July 2024 the group has repaired and rehomed dozens of unused bikes, run a weekly bike-to-school "bus" and a monthly "bike hospital" teaching locals how to repair and maintain their two-wheelers.

Mobilise TI has also crowdfunded $20,000 to ship 100 bikes to the island in the coming months.

"We're really focused on a cultural shift making bike riding more socially acceptable and culturally acceptable because it is quite novel still to see adults riding," Ms Tedder said.

"We figured if an adult has access to a bicycle then that might actually mean a whole family can get around more affordably and more sustainably."

The bike-to-school bus runs every Friday morning. (Supplied: Sarah Tedder)

Project targets local mums

Those who can't easily access a car have been the focus of the program.

Joy Robin sought help from the bike hospital last year to fix her daughter's bike and ended up receiving a second-hand bicycle of her own.

"[Before that] we were either walking or catching taxis or getting a lift from family members," Ms Robin said.

" It's so good being on the bike. It's reliable, it's there just ready for us to go, you've always got a breeze, keeps us healthy too. "

Thursday Island mum Joy Robin and daughter Linze with their bikes. (Supplied: Sarah Tedder)

Deannie Salam and her children have been riding every day since receiving their refurbished bikes this month.

"I'm using [the bike] to get to work, drop the kids at school, even get a few groceries," she said.

"I get to save a bit more money and not spend so much every day [on taxis]."

Breaking barriers

According to the 2021 Census, of those working on Thursday Island 23.3 per cent walked to work (2.6 per cent statewide), 1.3 per cent took a taxi/ride share (0.3 per cent statewide), 1.7 per cent rode (0.7 per cent statewide) and 39.1 per cent drove (59.5 per cent statewide).

While the data for bicycle and car use are favourable compared with statewide figures, Torres Shire Mayor Elsie Seriat wants them to be better.

"It's crazy now it seems that on TI we have more cars than people and the traffic is getting bad," Cr Seriat said.

The bike hospital is a vital service on an island with no bicycle mechanic. (Supplied: Sarah Tedder)

As a long-time fitness advocate, the health benefits from cycling aren't to be ignored either for the mayor in a community where more than 70 per cent of the population is First Nation.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people's life expectancy is eight years less on average than non-Indigenous Australians and lower still in remote areas, according to Australian Bureau of Statistics data.

First Nations people in the Torres Strait and nearby Cape York are dying of preventable diseases at more than twice the overall rate statewide.

Meanwhile several large-scale longitudinal studies overseas have found people who cycled to work reduced their risk of dying early by up to 47 per cent.

"Get our families out and have fun … [cycling] is good for our health and wellbeing and just to make time for ourselves," Cr Seriat said.

The mum-of-two, who also joins in with the bike-to-school bus and bike hospital, has been riding as much as she can since receiving a second-hand bike with a child's seat.

Elsie Seriat joins the bike-to-school bus whenever she's not travelling for work. (Supplied: Sarah Tedder)

"The looks I get from people in community when they see me on the bike is like, 'Hey, you're the mayor and you're riding a bike?'

"Breaking barriers is what I'm about," she said.

Global inspiration

After finding corporate sponsors and raising $20,000 through crowdfunding late last year, Ms Tedder is eagerly awaiting the arrival of a container load of 100 bicycles.

They'll be given to locals either for free or at a subsidised cost.

Mobilise TI is receiving applications from locals who want a free or subsidised bike. (Supplied: Sarah Tedder)

Ms Tedder said international movements inspired her to create a more bike-friendly Thursday Island, such as Amsterdam, the world's most bike-friendly city and the charity World Bicycle Relief, which has distributed more than 800,000 bikes to developing communities.

"We wanted to infuse the community with a whole bunch of bikes," she said.

"Bikes equipped to carry kids so mums and caregivers can ride and break down the perceived barriers around shame or embarrassment about doing something different."

title: From timber and potatoes to tourism, Penguin celebrates 150 years
text:
What is a name? In the seaside town of Penguin, it's something of a north star.

With the Big Penguin, and penguin-themed bins and bollards, the small but thriving Tasmanian town stands behind its name.

This year, the community of about 3,500 is celebrating 150 years, in signature Penguin style.

On Sunday, hundreds of locals kicked off the sesquicentenary by dressing in black and white, donning a penguin mask, and joining in the Great Penguin Waddle — flapping, hopping, and dancing along the foreshore.

Hundreds of people took part in The Great Penguin Waddle on Sunday. (ABC News: Bec Pridham)

Joseph von Moger at The Great Penguin Waddle. (ABC News: Bec Pridham)

Among the crowd was four-year-old Joseph von Moger, who not only acted accordingly — but had facts at hand.

"[Daddy penguins] put the eggs on their feet … [otherwise] they'll freeze," he said.

Noelene Hansen said it was great to embrace the community spirit.

"Besides, we're at the waddling age, and so we fit in quite well with the waddle," the 81-year-old said.

Locals embraced the community spirit at The Great Penguin Waddle. (ABC News: Bec Pridham)

So how did this town come to be?

British colonists first arrived in 1861 to find "impenetrable, heavily timbered coastline", Craig Dunham, a born and raised local and president of the Penguin History Group, said.

With demand for timber high in Victoria after the gold rush, a burgeoning local industry was born.

"All of a sudden, the little town thrived … so there was quite a bit of excitement," Mr Dunham said.

A man and a woman at a beach near Penguin in the early 20th century. (Supplied: Penguin History Group)

And in 1875, with about 300 residents, the town of Penguin was proclaimed.

In clearing the forest, another kind of wealth was uncovered.

"They discovered that the soil was very, very rich, and farming since that time, dairy and cropping particularly, have been very, very strong, and still are today," Mr Dunham said.

Craig Dunham says timber from Penguin fed demand in Victoria after the gold rush. (ABC News: Georgia Hogge)

Over time, while Burnie became an industrial hub, with the establishment of the pulp mill and titanium dioxide plant, Mr Dunham said Penguin served as the "dormitory neighbouring town" where workers returned home to.

"Penguin subsequently grew through that," he said.

"We've always been the small, little cousin type thing.

"I must say, it's been more of an evolution than a revolution.

" That's probably one of Penguin's greatest assets, that we haven't grown too quickly. "

Penguin's main street in 1922. (Supplied: Penguin History Group)

A cricket match in Penguin. (Supplied: Penguin History Group)

Big Penguin a highlight

In more recent times it's also enjoyed a stream of tourists, and there's no question as to what has lured visitors in.

The Big Penguin, standing three metres tall on the main drag, was built 50 years ago to celebrate the town's centenary.

"I've travelled myself, and often when people know you come from Penguin, [they say] 'we've been, we've seen the Big Penguin,'" Mr Dunham said.

The Big Penguin was built to mark the Penguin's centenary. (ABC Northern Tasmania: Monte Bovill)

A place for the living and the dead

The town is adored by its residents.

Ross Hartley moved to Penguin 20 years ago. He described the town as "a lovely little place".

Living a stone's throw away from the cemetery, which sits atop a hill and looks out to an expanse of sea, he became transfixed with a grave marked "John Doe" — a name used for unknown men.

He looked into it, only to find seven unmarked plots belonging to "paupers".

Craig Dunham says Penguin is Burnie's "little cousin". (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

Wanting to honour them with headstones, Mr Hartley turned to a less conventional fundraising approach — stripping.

Fortunate enough to know a theatre costume designer, he donned a custom-made kit of black pants "all velcro and zips", a little sleeveless vest, bow tie, striped socks and a hat.

"I'm not a dancer, I'm not a stripper, but I did my best," he said.

"It was just a fun time, I could never do it now, I look back and think, 'Ross, you did that'."

Ross Hartley says Penguin is "a lovely little place". (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

The plots were marked and the cemetery was heritage listed in 2007.

It motivated Mr Hartley to do more at the site. Since then, the graveyard has hosted dinners, and music amongst the gravestones.

"What we've tried to do, and have achieved to a large extent, is making it a place for the living as much as for the dead," Mr Hartley said.

Penguin bins here to stay as replacement plan trashed Photo shows A rubbish bin on a pathway with artwork of painted penguins In the town of Penguin, they love their bird-shaped bins so much a council plan to replace them was never going to fly.

More recently, the beloved penguin-themed bins were set to be trashed, to make way for new bins that weren't in keeping with the bird theme.

It prompted outrage from locals, who rallied against the council, submitting a petition to save them.

Mr Hartley went so far as submitting a heritage application, which was knocked back because they were not the original design.

But, ultimately, hearing the community's cries, the council decided not just to keep the bins, but to bring in more.

The Central Coast Council backtracked on a plan to remove the penguin-themed bins in Penguin. (ABC Northern Tasmania: Monte Bovill)

Central Coast Mayor Cheryl Fuller said while the town was small, it was memorable.

"If only the people that named the town of Penguin understood that in the future, and in 150 years' time, the people of this town and the people that live in the surrounding areas would come to actually represent the penguin," she said.

"It's small, it's iconic, it's cute, it's resilient, it's adaptable, and they take care of themselves in a colony of penguins, and that's exactly what the people of Penguin do."

Penguin residents are proud of their town. (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

As for Penguin's future, Mr Dunham is optimistic.

"We'll always be relatively small and keep that civic pride and sense of community," he said.

title: Travis Head hands Ashes rival Jofra Archer a record-breaking smashing in IPL
text:
Travis Head has helped condemn Ashes rival Jofra Archer to a record-breaking day of bowling misery as he kicked off his IPL season with a dazzling half-century for Pat Cummins's Sunrisers Hyderabad.

The Australian left-hander carried on where he left off in Hyderabad's terrific 2024 campaign as his blistering 67 off 31 balls launched the home team to the second-highest total in IPL history, a massive 6-286, on their way to a 44-run opening victory against Rajasthan Royals on Sunday.

The chief victim of Head's familiar brand of mayhem, as he raced to 50 off 21 balls, was England quick Archer, who was smashed by his Aussie rival for 23 off his first over, including a humungous six measuring 105 metres that soared into the crowd beyond deepest midwicket.

That was just the start of Archer's ordeal.

Even after Head departed, Ishan Kishan continued the rampage, scoring a century off just 45 balls with Archer on his menu too, as the Indian international hammered him for three sixes in an over.

By the end of his four overs, during which he had got so frazzled he even got warned for delivering a head-high beamer, Archer could only gaze forlornly on figures of 4-0-76-0 — the single worst analysis in the history of the league.

Jofra Archer was humbled in his four overs, conceding 76 runs for no wickets. (Getty Images: Pankaj Nangia)

One of the game's most feared pacemen had gone for four sixes and 10 fours, as Hyderabad went on to just miss out on eclipsing their IPL record 3-287 against Royal Challengers Bengaluru last year, with Kishan finishing 106 not out off 47.

There was surely no way the visitors could get near that total, but nothing is certain any more amid the IPL run-fests and Rajasthan gave it such a good go as they amassed 6-242 that Hyderabad captain Cummins had to admit: "It's scary…"

Australia's skipper himself found his bowling getting the treatment, as he recorded wretched figures of 0-60 off his four overs, having been hit for five sixes and four fours off his allocation.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

And his fellow Aussie Adam Zampa, used as an impact sub to replace Head, also got shoved around, going for 48 runs off his four, but at least he responded with the key scalp of Dhruv Jurel, bowling the top-scoring wicketkeeper who'd threatened with six sixes in his 35-ball 70.

It was the perfect start for Cummins, who'd led Sunrisers to the final last year and, now strengthened by new signing Kishan, has realistic hopes of going one better in 2025.

"It's unbelievable," Cummins said.

"We get 280-odd, and it's scary, you still know you're going to go for runs and it's going to be tough. When you have such a big score, one over can win it for your side. Ishan today was incredible for us."

In the evening match, Australian bowler Nathan Ellis had a winning debut for Chennai Super Kings, as the home side beat Mumbai Indians by four wickets with five balls remaining.

Ellis took 1-38 in his four overs, helping to keep Mumbai down to a sub-par 9-155 before New Zealander Rachin Ravindra guided Chennai home in an awkward chase with an unbeaten 65 off 45 balls.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP

title: Stuart furious with referee after Raiders defeat
text:
Ricky Stuart says he still doesn't understand the NRL's interpretations of obstruction rulings, despite sitting on a committee designed to crack down on players milking penalties.

Stuart claimed the NRL had abandoned its no-tolerance approach just three rounds into the season, after his Canberra side had a try chalked off in the 20th minute of Sunday's 40-12 loss at Manly.

Seb Kris broke the Sea Eagles line and touched down for what appeared to have been the game's first try.

But a bunker ruling called play back after minimal contact between Canberra prop Corey Horsburgh and Sea Eagles halfback Daly Cherry-Evans.

Manly captain Cherry-Evans initiated contact with Horsburgh and then raced after the play.

Raiders lock Morgan Smithies was hit by Haumole Olakau'atu after passing the ball that led to Kris's try.

Canberra then conceded a penalty for the contact with Cherry-Evans, Horsburgh was sin-binned soon after for a professional foul, and while the prop was off Manly chalked up 22 unanswered points.

Stuart and other prominent coaches were part of a committee including NRL administrators, which met to discuss rules over the summer.

But he said the interpretations agreed upon had "gone out the window".

He said Sunday's game proved his trip to Sydney for the rules summit was a "waste of two days".

"After 20 minutes, we had no football, and we got a set around halfway, and we score a wonderful try," Stuart said.

"It's really difficult coaching when you don't know rules, you don't know interpretations, because I've got no idea.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"We wanted to make defenders defend this year.

"This year, that was what the rule was when Wayne [Bennett] and Ivan [Cleary] and I sat down with Ashley [Klein], Andrew [Abdo] and Graham [Annesley].

"But that's gone out the window."

Stuart seemed to infer that the hit on Smithies would be officiated differently if he was a playmaker.

"My ballplayer got hit after he passed," Stuart said.

"If it was a couple of other players, I know exactly where the penalty would have gone. It was my bloke. But that whole game changed there.

"But something's changed this week, and I've got an idea [why]."

AAP

title: School camp has been a rite of passage but might be a thing of the past
text:
Tammy's son struggled with separation anxiety, and found the idea of spending time away from home "very triggering".

In recent years, school camps have really helped ease his nerves.

"He gets really anxious before he goes, but then when he's on camp, the teachers are really good with him," the mum from Ballarat said.

"The amount of personal growth he gets out of it is astronomical, and he's now having more and more sleepovers.

"When he came back [from camp], the amount of information that he could give us and being able to speak confidently about that at a school assembly was just amazing."

But school camps are becoming increasingly rare for Victorian state school students.

Since 2023, new provisions requiring educators to receive time-in-lieu for out-of-hours work have made school camps more difficult for schools to fund, despite the Fair Work Commission requiring the state government to add $130 million to school budgets to ensure camps could continue.

School camps are shown to be beneficial for kids' anxiety, team building and emotional development. (Supplied: Blue Light Youth Camp)

Previously, teachers were not compensated for the extra hours spent at camps.

Despite the Fair Work Commission ruling, financial strains are forcing many schools to reduce camps to every second year, shorten their duration or cut back altogether, opting for day excursions instead.

Tammy says she is lucky her son's primary school is continuing to subsidise the costs of camp.

"But a lot of schools aren't as fortunate to have a committee that does the same thing," she said.

Camp owners witnessing decline

In Victoria's south-west, Kangaroobie School Camp owner and manager Sophie Bowker has seen the decline in school camps first-hand.

"We've seen lots of changes, especially in the last couple of years since the time-in-lieu arrangement changed," Ms Bowker said.

"Schools that have been coming to us for 20 years have had to cancel due to the time-in-lieu agreement because they can't afford it anymore."

She said since 2023, 10 schools, mainly from Melbourne, have stopped coming to Kangaroobie which was worth "close to $200,000".

Canoeing is among the activities on offer at Log Cabin Camp near Ballarat. (Supplied: Log Cabin Camp)

Grant Laidlaw owns and runs two camps north of Ballarat, Log Cabin Camp in Creswick and Adekate Camp in Dean.

School camps on chopping block Photo shows About six colourful camping tents spread out among trees on long grass Principals in Victoria say they're doing everything they can to keep the tradition of school camps going — including attending the camps themselves.

He said the time-in-lieu change was a factor, but so were rising living costs for parents and schools.

"For a two-night camp, you'd be looking at $400 to $500 easily," Mr Laidlaw said.

"It's not just one factor, buses have become a lot more expensive as well as time-in-lieu [for the teachers].

"So if you've got to travel three hours on a bus with a bunch of kids, you're looking at thousands and thousands of dollars.

"It's not ideal for us as a business, we had a few four-night camps and some of those have dropped back to two nights … and camps coming for two nights [have gone] down to day visits."

A valued part of schooling

Mr Laidlaw says he is hopeful things will turn around, as camps are a vital part of students' education.

"The industry is putting science up and empirical evidence to show that camping is beneficial for kids' anxiety, for team building, for their emotional development, for learning other skills, for engaging with nature," he said.

"Why can't teachers be paid a little bit more, because it's not just about camps, it's also about taking kids to a dance production out of hours or to see a show in Melbourne.

School camps are a rite of passage for students. (ABC News: Sharon Gordon)

"People need to be proactive, so if you value something, you will give resources and time to it."

The Australian Education Union said in a statement that while "school camps are an important part of schooling for all students, school staff should be paid for all the work that they undertake".

"It is incumbent on the government to properly and fully fund schools so that staff members are adequately compensated for working outside of regular hours, just like every other worker should be," the union said.

The Department of Education and the Minister for Education have been contacted for comment.

title: Teens struggle to adjust to adult life after leaving out-of-home care
text:
Timothy Noakes is a survivor of the Northern Territory's out-of-home care system.

He was 15 when he transitioned to independent living and still remembers how it felt.

"It's like a stigma you know, you're always cast as an orphan but really you're just a person looking for family and a place to stay," the now-20-year-old said.

Leaving care, Mr Noakes received a $1,500 one-off payment from the Commonwealth and supports from the NT government, but it wasn't enough to set up a home.

Mr Noakes says he struggled to afford the basics after transitioning to independent living. (ABC News: Tristan Hooft)

"I really wanted to feel safe and a lot of it didn't feel safe to me," he said.

"Just not being able to afford the day-to-day shopping or items I need like … a fridge and bed."

The NT has the highest rate of kids in care in Australia

More than 55,000 Australian children had at least one placement in out-of-home care last year.

The highest rate of kids in care was reported in the NT and almost nine in 10 of those children were First Nations.

Eric Majindi is living with the consequences of that system.

Raised in Darwin, the 19-year-old doesn't understand the language or culture of his Wadeye or Tiwi Islands relatives.

"I want to learn a bit more of the language and culture but I'm just disconnected from them for a very long time," he said.

Mr Majindi said he wanted governments to see the value in supporting families, before children are removed.

Eric Majindi says growing up in care meant he was disconnected from his culture. (ABC News: Tristan Hooft)

He said being raised with or near his Aboriginal family would have changed his life.

"I would be able to feel normal and not so isolated during a very important time in my life," he said.

" I wouldn't have had to grow up so fast. "

Leaving residential care at 18 with no place to go

Eighteen-year-old Fantasia Portaminni says her placement in care was driven in part by her family's struggles with homelessness in Darwin.

She left residential care last year because she was turning 18 and it raised old insecurities.

"I was just confused where I was going to go," she said.

Ms Portaminni said many of her peers had ended up homeless after being sent back to families that didn't have houses, or being placed on decade-long social housing waitlists.

"Soon after [out-of-home care provider CASPA] told me they had a place waiting for me and then that's when I felt more better," she said.

Fantasia Portaminni says she was "confused" about where to go after leaving residential care. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

Her new home is a small apartment in a notoriously dangerous part of suburban Darwin.

To keep safe she "stays small", sitting in the dark of her apartment when violence erupts outside.

But she said her homeless friends were far worse off.

"It's not fair … they don't get to stay or do what I am doing and have their space, they are just moving around," she said.

Thousands of children aged 15 to 17 transition out of care every year.

The supports available to them are pot luck, with states and territories offering different levels of post care, transition and extended care packages.

Ms Portaminni now dreams of becoming a landscape gardener with the Darwin council. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

Imogen Edeson, the chief executive of national consumer body CREATE, which represents young people with out-of-home care experience, said all states and territories offered some sort of transition.

But she said it created "a kind of postcode bias".

"I think having some consistency across all states and territories would be really helpful, and also more transparency," Ms Edeson said.

A brighter future

In Darwin, care leaver Terence Puruntatameri had secured a job and accommodation in his transition to independent living.

Before he turned 18, Mr Puruntatameri was living in a government-funded children's home but had to leave when he became an adult to move to independent living.

He now works as a trainee with CASPA's charitable arm, Hammers 4 Hope, a not-for-profit providing grounds and building maintenance at CASPA's 11 residential care facilities in the Top End.

"When I first started I was a bit anxious and that but later down the track I felt more comfortable with the tools and working my way around a job site," Mr Puruntatameri said.

Terence Puruntatameri says he became more confident on job sites after starting a traineeship with Hammers 4 Hope. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

Mentor Scott Sharpe has trained eight care leavers under Hammers 4 Hope and said Mr Puruntatameri had worked hard and was ready for an apprenticeship.

"I've seen him grow, I have seen what he has achieved. I am really proud of who he is and the person he is becoming," Mr Sharpe said.

Without supports, the road to success is challenging.

"All the time I just feel like I am going to fall off but I just keep getting back up," Mr Puruntatameri said.

"I just want to be a carpenter."

title: Live: Extra $150 off power bills as energy shapes up as key election issue
text:
The Coalition says it's not cutting the National Disability Insurance Scheme, calling that a "false accusation from a desperate government".

Labor had swiftly hit out at comments from Shadow Finance Minister Jane Hume yesterday, when she said NDIS growth was out of control and more needed to be done.

Here's what she told Sky News:

"Australians should take great comfort in knowing that a Coalition government will not be making cuts to frontline services or essential services. But at some stage, those hard decisions about where we're going to make changes have to be considered. "The NDIS, for instance, is one of those areas in the budget that has run out of control. It was growing at 14 per cent per annum. "Now, when we went into opposition, the Coalition said to the government that we would work with them to rein in that spending and get it under control. It's been brought back to around 8 per cent. It actually looks like it's going to be much higher than that this year, but it's been brought under control somewhat. We think that there's more that can be done. We would hope that when Labor goes into opposition, that they would work with us to try and rein in that."

The Coalition argues her comment about "more that can be done" was because the scheme's growth was yet to reach the government's target of eight per cent. (The government says it'll get there by mid next year.)

But NDIS Minister Amanda Rishworth says Senator Hume's remarks raise big questions.

"The comments by Jane Hume suggests that there are cuts going to come, so she's got to explain what supports are going to be cut for people with disabilities. Who's going to be kicked off the NDIS?" she told ABC News. "They are the questions — they now need to be upfront and tell people before an election."

A spokesperson for NDIS Shadow Minister Michael Sukkar said the Coalition is "focused on ensuring the NDIS remains fit for purpose and sustainable for future generations to come."

title: Feng shui and fortune: Robertson home soars to $2.51 million at auction
text:
It had ’70s carpet, peeling wallpaper, a kitchen in dire need of an upgrade and a wonky block.

But that didn’t stop five families duking it out at a fierce auction in one of Brisbane’s most tightly held pockets, driving the price to a jaw-dropping $2.51 million.

The four-bedroom house, at 23 Janda Street, Robertson, sits on an 817 square metre block and has remained in the same hands since it was built 47 years ago. But despite its need of a renovation, the home soared $100,000 past its reserve and hundreds of thousands beyond the vendor’s expectations.

Selling agent Alex Fan, of LJ Hooker Property Partners, said while even run-down homes in Robertson were sitting on a pot of gold, the result was a jaw-dropper.
